9/9/20

Dear Bureau Valley Junior High Parents and Students,

In March 2020 the Bureau Valley School Board approved the addition of a BVJH JFL Program for the 2020/21 school year. We have been looking forward to a successful 2020 first season and a lot of hard work went into planning and preparing for our first year. However, according to the IDPH Sports Safety Guidance, football is placed into the highest risk category and teams are not allowed to participate in any contact practices, scrimmages or competitive play at this time. For the safety of our students, and in alignment with IESA, IHSA and the IDPH guidance, we regret to inform you that we are cancelling the BVJH JFL 2020 season. We will now turn our vision and attention to our 2021/22 season and look forward to building a successful program that will grow each year and enhance the high school football program for years to come.

post_text: In conjunction with the board-approved Return to Learn Plan and fall registration, the administrative team had hoped to send out a form today to give parents the opportunity to choose between the in-person learning plan or full-time remote learning plan. However, the Illinois State Board of Education released a 103-page update of school recommendations yesterday, which will need to be closely reviewed and considered. Therefore, we have decided to send out the "Parent Selection" form next week along with an FAQ to assist families with their selections and respond to concerns shared in the community survey emailed earlier this week. To correspond with this delay, we will extend the deadline to opt into full remote learning beyond the original July 31st deadline to August 5th.

post_text: BVHS Interact Club does demonstration of Composting Program for Kewanee High School!
shared_text:
Bureau Valley High School
March 2 at 10:36 AM ·

Three students from Bureau Valley High School's Interact Club and Mrs. Nichols, sponsor of the German Club, traveled to Kewanee High School on February 26th to teach interested staff and students about school food-waste solutions. Jacob Benavidez, Ethen Webb, Brooklynn Cade and Mrs. Nichols hauled seven working worm bins to the school so that the twenty participants could dig in and see the worm farm in action. The German Club donated 4,000 worms to get KHS started with their own worm composting project and supplied them with shredded newspapers and sawdust captured from the school's waste stream.

The composting program at BVHS involves both the Jr. High and High School Interact Clubs, the Life Skills Class, the German Club, and Botany and Food Science classes. Grants from the Bureau Valley School Foundation have funded most of the compost system expenses. To date, the initiative has processed over three tons of food waste from the school.
